pageProps.contentHtml:
harmonic functions

Let p1,p2,…,pnp_1, p_2, \ldots, p_np1​,p2​,…,pn​ be distinct points in the complex plane C\CC and let UUU be the domain

U=C∖{p1,…,pn}.U = \C \setminus \set{p_1, \ldots, p_n}.U=C∖{p1​,…,pn​}.

Let AAA be the vector space of real harmonic functions on UUU and let B⊆AB \subseteq AB⊆A be the subspace of real parts of complex analytic functions on UUU. Find the dimension of the quotient vector space A/BA/BA/B, give a basis for this quotient space, and prove that it is a basis.
Solution.

We claim that if uk(z)=log⁡∣z−pk∣u_k\p{z} = \log\abs{z - p_k}uk​(z)=log∣z−pk​∣, then {u1,…,un}\set{u_1, \ldots, u_n}{u1​,…,un​} is a basis for A/BA/BA/B. In particular, dim⁡(A/B)=n\dim\p{A/B} = ndim(A/B)=n.

Write pk=ak+bkip_k = a_k + b_kipk​=ak​+bk​i so that uk(x,y)=12log⁡((x−ak)2+(y−bk)2)u_k\p{x, y} = \frac{1}{2}\log\p{\p{x - a_k}^2 + \p{y - b_k}^2}uk​(x,y)=21​log((x−ak​)2+(y−bk​)2). Thus,

∂2uk∂x2=−(x−ak)2+(y−bk)2∣z−pk∣4and∂2uk∂x2=(x−ak)2−(y−bk)2∣z−pk∣4.\frac{\partial^2 u_k}{\partial x^2} = \frac{-\p{x - a_k}^2 + \p{y - b_k}^2}{\abs{z - p_k}^4} \quad\text{and}\quad \frac{\partial^2 u_k}{\partial x^2} = \frac{\p{x - a_k}^2 - \p{y - b_k}^2}{\abs{z - p_k}^4}.∂x2∂2uk​​=∣z−pk​∣4−(x−ak​)2+(y−bk​)2​and∂x2∂2uk​​=∣z−pk​∣4(x−ak​)2−(y−bk​)2​.

Hence, Δuk=0\Delta u_k = 0Δuk​=0, which means uk∈Au_k \in Auk​∈A for all 1≤k≤n1 \leq k \leq n1≤k≤n.

Let γk\gamma_kγk​ be a small circle oriented counter-clockwise centered around pkp_kpk​ with radius rkr_krk​ small enough so that the γk\gamma_kγk​ are pairwise disjoint. Then

∫γkuk(z) dz=∫02πlog⁡ ∣rk∣ dθ=2πlog⁡ ∣rk∣.\int_{\gamma_k} u_k\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \int_0^{2\pi} \log\,\abs{r_k} \,\diff\theta = 2\pi\log\,\abs{r_k}.∫γk​​uk​(z)dz=∫02π​log∣rk​∣dθ=2πlog∣rk​∣.

This tells us that near pkp_kpk​, uku_kuk​ is not the real part of a holomorphic function. Indeed, if that were not the case, then Cauchy's theorem implies that this integral would be independent of the radius rkr_krk​.

Next, if we define the conjugate differential of u∈Au \in Au∈A to be ∗du=−uy dx+ux dy{}^*\diff{u} = -u_y \,\diff{x} + u_x \,\diff{y}∗du=−uy​dx+ux​dy, then

∗duk=−y−bk∣z−pk∣2 dx+x−ak∣z−pk∣2 dy.{}^*\diff{u_k} = -\frac{y - b_k}{\abs{z - p_k}^2} \,\diff{x} + \frac{x - a_k}{\abs{z - p_k}^2} \,\diff{y}.∗duk​=−∣z−pk​∣2y−bk​​dx+∣z−pk​∣2x−ak​​dy.

Also, notice that uk=Re⁡(log⁡(z−pk))u_k = \Re\p{\log\p{z - p_k}}uk​=Re(log(z−pk​)). So, if k≠ℓk \neq \ellk=ℓ, log⁡(z−pk)\log\p{z - p_k}log(z−pk​) is holomorphic on the ball B(pℓ,rk)B\p{p_\ell, r_k}B(pℓ​,rk​) and so v=Im⁡(log⁡(z−pk))v = \Im\p{\log\p{z - p_k}}v=Im(log(z−pk​)) satisfies dv=∗duk\diff{v} = {}^*\diff{u_k}dv=∗duk​, so ∫γℓ∗duk=0\int_{\gamma_\ell} {}^*\diff{u_k} = 0∫γℓ​​∗duk​=0. Otherwise, if k=ℓk = \ellk=ℓ, then we can parametrize γk\gamma_kγk​ via z=pk+rkeiθz = p_k + r_ke^{i\theta}z=pk​+rk​eiθ, which gives

∫γk∗duk=∫02π−rksin⁡θrk2(−rksin⁡θ)+rkcos⁡θrk2rkcos⁡θ dθ=∫02π dθ=2π.\begin{aligned} \int_{\gamma_k} {}^*\diff{u_k} &= \int_0^{2\pi} -\frac{r_k\sin\theta}{r_k^2} \p{-r_k\sin\theta} + \frac{r_k\cos\theta}{r_k^2} r_k\cos\theta \,\diff\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} \,\diff\theta \\ &= 2\pi. \end{aligned}∫γk​​∗duk​​=∫02π​−rk2​rk​sinθ​(−rk​sinθ)+rk2​rk​cosθ​rk​cosθdθ=∫02π​dθ=2π.​

This implies that the uku_kuk​ are linearly independent:

c1u1+⋯+cnun=0  ⟹  ∫γkc1∗du1+⋯+cn∗du1=0  ⟹  2πck=0  ⟹  ck=0\begin{aligned} c_1u_1 + \cdots + c_nu_n = 0 &\implies \int_{\gamma_k} c_1 {}^*\diff{u_1} + \cdots + c_n {}^*\diff{u_1} = 0 \\ &\implies 2\pi c_k = 0 \\ &\implies c_k = 0 \end{aligned}c1​u1​+⋯+cn​un​=0​⟹∫γk​​c1​∗du1​+⋯+cn​∗du1​=0⟹2πck​=0⟹ck​=0​

for any kkk. It remains to show that the uku_kuk​ form a basis. Let u∈Au \in Au∈A and set ck=∫γk∗duc_k = \int_{\gamma_k} {}^*\diff{u}ck​=∫γk​​∗du. Consider

u~=u−12π∑k=1nckuk.\tilde{u} = u - \frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{k=1}^n c_ku_k.u~=u−2π1​k=1∑n​ck​uk​.

u~\tilde{u}u~ is harmonic, and its conjugate differential satisfies

∫γℓ∗du~=∫γℓ∗du−12π∑k=1nck∫γℓ∗duk=ck−ck=0\int_{\gamma_\ell} {}^*\diff{\tilde{u}} = \int_{\gamma_\ell} {}^*\diff{u} - \frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \int_{\gamma_\ell} {}^*\diff{u_k} = c_k - c_k = 0∫γℓ​​∗du~=∫γℓ​​∗du−2π1​k=1∑n​ck​∫γℓ​​∗duk​=ck​−ck​=0

for all 1≤ℓ≤n1 \leq \ell \leq n1≤ℓ≤n. Set f(z)=u~x−iu~yf\p{z} = \tilde{u}_x - i\tilde{u}_yf(z)=u~x​−iu~y​ so that f dz=du~+i∗du~f \,\diff{z} = \diff{\tilde{u}} + i{}^*\diff{\tilde{u}}fdz=du~+i∗du~. Notice that fff is holomorphic since it satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations. Hence, if γ\gammaγ is any simple closed curve in UUU, let mkm_kmk​ be the winding number of γ\gammaγ around pkp_kpk​ and σ=γ−∑k=1nmkγk\sigma = \gamma - \sum_{k=1}^n m_k\gamma_kσ=γ−∑k=1n​mk​γk​, which gives

∫σf(z) dz=0\int_\sigma f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = 0∫σ​f(z)dz=0

by the residue theorem: fff can only have poles at p1,…,pnp_1, \ldots, p_np1​,…,pn​, and we cancel out the residues in the sum via the γk\gamma_kγk​. Since du\diff{u}du is exact and γ\gammaγ is closed,

0=∫σf(z) dz=∫σ(du~+i∗du~)=i∫σ∗du~.0 = \int_\sigma f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \int_\sigma \p{\diff{\tilde{u}} + i{}^*\diff{\tilde{u}}} = i\int_\sigma {}^*\diff{\tilde{u}}.0=∫σ​f(z)dz=∫σ​(du~+i∗du~)=i∫σ​∗du~.

Thus,

∫γ∗du~=∑k=1nmk∫γk∗du~=0.\int_\gamma {}^*\diff{\tilde{u}} = \sum_{k=1}^n m_k \int_{\gamma_k} {}^*\diff{\tilde{u}} = 0.∫γ​∗du~=k=1∑n​mk​∫γk​​∗du~=0.

In other words, ∗du~{}^*\diff{\tilde{u}}∗du~ is conservative, and so

v(z)=∫γz0→z∗du~v\p{z} = \int_{\gamma_{z_0\to z}} {}^*\diff{\tilde{u}}v(z)=∫γz0​→z​​∗du~

is a well-defined harmonic conjugate to u~\tilde{u}u~. This means that u~\tilde{u}u~ is the real part of a holomorphic function on UUU, so u−12π∑k=1nckuk∈Bu - \frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{k=1}^n c_ku_k \in Bu−2π1​∑k=1n​ck​uk​∈B, which shows that {u1,…,un}\set{u_1, \ldots, u_n}{u1​,…,un​} spans A/BA/BA/B, so it is a basis for A/BA/BA/B.
